1t will be seen that the terms in which this order
is expressed, proves that Gen. Jackson was him.
self ignorant of the law. His calling out of the mi.
litia on the Gath May, 1914, for the period of sr
months was itselfa violation OF the law. After the
18th of April, 1914 the militia could not be called
ou for longer term Of service than three months.
No State authority could, under any circumstances,
require them to serve for longer period. The
President of the United States only authorized
by the law, it, in has opinion the public interest re-
qured it, to retain them in service for more than
three months and any attempt to compel them 10
serve tor longer period, without the special order
of the President, was Illegal There was no such
order. The Editor Of the Telegraph says. vi
kas.u no sueh order eristed" How did he know this
but from General Jackson himself!


But, says The Telegraph, owe knew more; that
IN no case, where militia called into service
under the act of 1912, did the President issue an or
der requiring them TO SIX months ; and thai
in all cases, the call was not liited to a le:
term, the militia were mustered for months" Al
this show OF legal know ledge, and al the differences
intended TO be grounded upon ii, amount, to nothing
inasmuch as the act of 1872 had become detunct, b,
its provision OF limitation. five weeks before th
order calling out TIE militia, IN TINS case, was issued
and the OF 795. with the qualification con aimee
in the act OF April l8, 1914, the only law in ex
lstence.


We must again refer to the order of General ack
son calling out these militia in order to show tha
the great stress laid by his defenders from this lille
gal charge of illegal execution on the alarming stat
of the country, the necessity of making stern exaI
pie in order to preserve the discipline of the troop
IN the presence Of poaperm enemy, and the urgenc
of the occasion, which rendered it indispensable th;
these should be in the field, is merely the hg
coloring ottancy, and is not supportahle in point
fact. These militia were called ont merely to ga
rlson and retain possession OF the territory eonque
ed from the Creeks, until appropriated by til
government and to relieve the troops then i'll ga
rlson. his fact removes another of the gronn,
on which the severity of General Jackson. in TIA
instance, has been justified, and converted into
positive merit.

GREAT SOUTH WESTERN ROAD.
full articles.article:
This pro ect naturally excites great interest in
the people Of the states through which it is 10 run.
Five of these II viii pass through entire, besides
ming through large portions Of others. A writer in
the Scoto Gazette, computes that the population of
these five eullre states will by the year 1880,
ceed two nmons, five hundred thousand, who pay
annually into the Treasury, including their purchase
OF the public lands not less than five millions of dol
lars Though not obligatory on government, it is
vet reasonable, il is added, that the disbursements
in works 4 public benefit in different sections Of the
country. sho.ld bear some proportion to their con-
trlbnti0ns % the public reasure. With certain linn


tailons this IS rae. The project in question, how
ever, will he Of high advantage TO the country at
large. ltwIil furnish facilities to the commercial
exchange, u remote sections, and give substantial
advantages to the General Government in the in
creased speed and greater certainty OF arrival, of
the mail.


The corps Of Typographical Engineers have es-
tmated tle expense OF this road at 81 900 a mile
IN the Nj Ad, plan, ,n uins the necessary bridges
The d'sance from GAINESVILLE. the point of diver
gency fiolh ts Cumberland hoad, 10 New Orleans,
may lie about 500 miles, ulaking the whole cost of
the road three millions five hundred thousand dol
lars The writer states that in the opinion Of the
Post Master General, the completion of the Road
would accelerate the speed the mail thirty miles
day. In twenty-five years, the whole expenses of
construction woud pfoDdbiy be reimbursed to GOV


ernnent by the resulting economy in the transuor


tation of the mail. In order to repress jealousy.


and equaze the epublc disbursements, in the respec


tive states, IT is suggested that the road be divided


into three great sections, to be commenced smulta-


neonsly the first to begin at Gainesville, in Ohio.


and to teripnate at Limestone. the south bank of


the Ohio River, in Kentucky; the second TO com


menceat Limestone, anc to end at Nashville in Ten
f nessce and the third to begin at the last named


point. and to extend TO New-Orleans, or 10 where


i shall ln'ersect the contemplated Southern Mail
Road from Washington to Louisiana.


t The following remarks contain, we believe. tbe
sentiments OF a large portion Of the American pub
nc sentiments which we hope to see prevail oyel


the temporary and extrinsic excitement which part,
n rage can give 10 any object.


1t is now too late in the day to raise the obieco,
IS mat Congress does not possess the power under thu
Consultation to make this road That question has
as in the example of the Cumberland Road, and 9th
n er public works Of similar character. been lon
al since soemny settled by Congress and their dec
a sion has bnen acquesced in by large majority
IT, the Intelligent and rejecting people of the Unite
to States: ard if il were deemed at all necessary,
I'd might add, this point, that very learned iuri
by one who for his talents as profound LAWYER h;
les long stood at the head the profession in Anne rca
CT mas sad. " there as any pavser conferred by Il

Constitution, II is The potrer TO consiruct Roads roas
the several States"


The construction of great public works belo,,
to no party; they only belong to the memory \
the age in which they are projected, and TO the oh
ry of those, who by their superior wisdom and for
cast, recommend them as suitable objects uua
which States should expend their National r.
sources Of money and labor, in preference to en-
ploying them in delugng the earth with the Blood
their subjects.

rhst The militia, when called into the service il
e The IIrted States by virtue Of the beUre recited
act 1.-THE act of 1885, which limits the term of SER
vice to three months. may If in the opinion OF the
president of the United States, the public interest
require it, be compelled to serve for term not ex-
ceedng six months after their arrival the place cf
rendezvous, in any one year."
The above facts will satisfy the reader that body
of militia called into service after the 10th OF April
1914, could not be subject to the law Of 1872 on
which the Editor Of the Telegraph relies for the ac-
quittal of Gen. jackson from the charge of an ie-
gal execution of the militia men. The order under
which the regiment. to which Harris and the other
militia men executed. was called out, is follows


MAY "a. 1924.
Bruue 7enesseans of The Cd Duision-lhe
Greek war, through the Divine aid of Providence,
and the valor Of those engaged in the campaign. IN
which you bore conspicuous share, has been
brought to happy termination. Good policy re-
qures that the territory conquered should be garr
soned, and possession retained until appropriated
by the government of the United States. In pur
suance ofths policy, to garrison d retain posses
sion of the Territory and to relieve the troops now
stationed at forts Williams Strother and Armstrong,
on the Coosa river, as we'll as Old and New Deposit,
] commanded by his excellency Governor
Blount. to call from my division one thousand men
in the service Of the United States, for the period
Of six months, unless discharged by order Of





The Brgader Generals, or officers commanding
the 4th. 5h, 9th. 7lh and 9th Brgades Of the cd
Division, will forthwith furnish from heir brigade,
respectively, by drafts or Uolioatary enhsmea two
hundred men. with two captains Two first, two Sc
cond. and two third lieutenants, and TWO ensigns.
well armed and equipped for actual service, to be
rendezvoused at Fayetteville. Lincoln county, in
the state OF Tennessee. ON the goth OF June next
and be organized into regiment. at winch place
the held officers and Will he ordered
to meet them.


Officers commanding the Brigades composing the
ed division of Tennessee militia, charged with
the prompt and due execution Of this order.


ANDREW JACKSON. Mai. General,


Commanding Cd Division T. NJ


1t will be seen that the terms in which this order
is expressed, proves that Gen. Jackson was him.
self ignorant of the law. His calling out of the mi.
litia on the Gath May, 1914, for the period of sr
months was itselfa violation OF the law. After the
18th of April, 1914 the militia could not be called
ou for longer term Of service than three months.
No State authority could, under any circumstances,
require them to serve for longer period. The
President of the United States only authorized
by the law, it, in has opinion the public interest re-
qured it, to retain them in service for more than
three months and any attempt to compel them 10
serve tor longer period, without the special order
of the President, was Illegal There was no such
order. The Editor Of the Telegraph says. vi
kas.u no sueh order eristed" How did he know this
but from General Jackson himself!


But, says The Telegraph, owe knew more; that
IN no case, where militia called into service
under the act of 1912, did the President issue an or
der requiring them TO SIX months ; and thai
in all cases, the call was not liited to a le:
term, the militia were mustered for months" Al
this show OF legal know ledge, and al the differences
intended TO be grounded upon ii, amount, to nothing
inasmuch as the act of 1872 had become detunct, b,
its provision OF limitation. five weeks before th
order calling out TIE militia, IN TINS case, was issued
and the OF 795. with the qualification con aimee
in the act OF April l8, 1914, the only law in ex
lstence.


We must again refer to the order of General ack
son calling out these militia in order to show tha
the great stress laid by his defenders from this lille
gal charge of illegal execution on the alarming stat
of the country, the necessity of making stern exaI
pie in order to preserve the discipline of the troop
IN the presence Of poaperm enemy, and the urgenc
of the occasion, which rendered it indispensable th;
these should be in the field, is merely the hg
coloring ottancy, and is not supportahle in point
fact. These militia were called ont merely to ga
rlson and retain possession OF the territory eonque
ed from the Creeks, until appropriated by til
government and to relieve the troops then i'll ga
rlson. his fact removes another of the gronn,
on which the severity of General Jackson. in TIA
instance, has been justified, and converted into
positive merit.


As the sole object of this article is to furnish IL
public with the materials for an accurate nlgne
as to the legality or egaity OF the conduct Of Ge
jackson, we shall close.lt with brief and smp
condensation of the points which are deducibe fro
the facts We have stated


1st. 1t is clear from the order of Gen. Jackso
that the reg giment of militia to which Harris and
fellow sufferers belonged, was directed to ren,le
vous at Fayetteville on the 2Uth June, 1911.

full articles.article:

living in or near the following places, if they v1
call, at once, on the following named Gentlemen
may obtain some important intelligence which can.
not. with much propriety, be made public Each Of
them is at liberty to select, and take along with him.
one good and substantial friend to the cause but
on no account, todiyulse the information which NAV
be received.

full articles.article:
.4ccusation.


General Jackson, at his own fre-side. and in print
declared that he could have been made president
had he consented to make Mr.. Clay Secretary o.
State and for proof, that this declaration was no
sander. he referred to Mr.. James Buchanan, d
Pennsylvania.


Mr.. Buchanan declared, in his letter of Aususts
that he called upon General Jackson, solely as BIZ
friend on his own responsibility, and not as the a
gent Of Mr.. Clay or any other person and that he
never made such proposition to the General ehe a
in the name Of Mr.. Clay or his friends.


.4ccasation.


Major Eaton, who loaned his s own money!
1900 Dollars--to Simpson-who had been support
ing the General for l8 nonths-said or nsnuate

Clay. and of course authorised to make propositions
or ask pledge of conditional character, for til
vote of Mr.. Clay and his friends.


Proof.


Mr.. Markley says, Oct. 30,-H do now solemn
ly and positively declare, that the charge and inn
uation are void of truth. never did, either directly
or indirectly, receive from Mr. Clay or his j,iMdt
any intmatoa which could be construed even By
political rancour, into such commission, or anil
thing even remotely approaching it. will g. fu.1
ther, and state, that never did |, in the of
ny conversation with Mr.. Clay, hear him say or eS
press desire, that in the event Of the election oil
Gen. Jackson, Mr. Adams, or Mr.. Crawford, he
should wish to be Secretary Of State, or hold any
station in the cabinet Further, never have TO-
amy one, at any time, any occasion, represent
ed myself or wished it to be understood that was
authorised to receive, or to make overtures on the
part Of Mr.. Clay or has friends. think proper 10
make this general and unqualified declaration, has
there may not be left loop to hang doubt on ID
this subject"


1t is in this satisfactory way, that these grave
charges are proved! Are these Pennsylvania W.T.
nesses not to be believed Is Mr.. Markley not TO
be credited, because he now holds an office under
government, solicited for him by most of his brother
Jacksonians in Congress Wel--put him aside. Is
Mr.. Buchanan, also, not TO be believed that mem
ber of Congress of high responsibility ~ He denies
point blank that he called on the General as the a.
gent Of Mr. Clay, or any other person, but on BIZ
own responsibility. He never as much as imagined
that, till time during last summer, second
Washington supposed he had made any proposition
TO him on the part of Mr.. Clay or his friends WI
you disgrace your own chosen witness---your ma
of such high responsibility Oris,General jackson
who cannot be president unless the character OF 10
Administration be ruined and Major Eaton, wh
lends " his own money" to Stephen Simpson, to D
fully credited, while these Pennsy ylvania Jacksonia
are to be pronounced unworthy of belief? Pleas
to settle this point, gentlemen. We want TO kn0
who, among all these Jacksonians, are to be belle
ed. Have the General and his Major less at sta
t in this business tfan the Pennsylvanians Do TIT
know more on this subject than the witness fro
!, whom alone they derived their information
9 short, gentlemen, do your own chosen witness Ut
If they do--just say so-and that will enable you
e call upon ssms other person for his testimony OBJ

5thly That the trials, convictions, and execu-
